comments: Good cooler, keeps my Ryzen 5 7600X under 80°C and fits in a mini-ITX case. Thermal paste wasn't very fluid though, you could probably buy some.
Decently easy assembly. (am5) Cools my 9800x3d more than enough. Fans were a bit loud for my liking, but still much more silent compared to my last PC.
It's big, it's a little awkward installing... but it's effective and pretty with RGB fans! And for $35??!?!? Fantastic!

Super smooth and quiet, both when idle and under load. Sadly, the motherboard's UEFI menu didn't let it run at zero fan speed, even after going through what Asus calls 'Q-fan Tuning' (which tries to detect the lowest supported fan speed for all fans). The lowest it let me go was 15%.
Installation was pretty straightforward. The fan comes with thermal paste, so you don't have to buy it separately. The fan cables also have adapters to daisy-chain them. However, the heat sink has sharp fins, so take care not to cut yourself (which happened to me 😅).
Working just fine, quiet too. That's why it's always recommended.
Easy to install and keeps things cool. Kept a 7600x at 85 degrees in Cinebench in my most recent build.
You will not regret getting this cooler. Inexpensive, but extremely powerful. Will keep your CPU cool through a camel ride through the sahara! Excellent price to performance
One of, if not; the best Air cpu coolers on the market.

This is an incredible value product, keeping my Ryzen 7 7700X CPU down to a cool 64 C even under a full gaming load. Two cooling towers, two fans, and 6 heat pipes connecting both towers for a very low cost of under $CDN 50 which both undercuts and performs just as well as similar two tower air coolers from more well-known brands. Highly recommended.
Does great at cooling my 7800X3D. No problem at all with temps.

comments: Worked great as a temporary cooler. Fan noise could be better
Only used this for a 4690k. Seems good enough only bought the black edition bc sale around 15€
The 212 Black is a pretty decent and cheap CPU fan. It gets the job done and looks much better than the 212 EVO.
Really like the way it connects to the board, but really wish the way the fans connect to the radiator was a little better. A bit flimsy imo.

It works alright and doesn't let my CPU melt, but for its size, I would've expected better cooling capacity, it's about 40°C on idle with an AMD Ryzen 7 3700X.
Update: The temperatures are actually acceptable, I'm just too used to laptop temperatures. Does a good job of preventing the CPU from climbing much higher than ~70°C, even at very high loads, and brings it back down fairly quickly. Rather quiet for its size, I think, anyway.
Has no problem cooling this CPU. Will update info.
Is a little loud, but works very well.
Ran out to BestBuy on the day of my build. Got it for $30 or so and has been great. Jerry-rigged another fan onto it for better cooling and its been solid. Can't complain
Going on year three operates around 50 Celsius with every CPU I've thrown at it. Staple of it's market.
I was swayed by all the years of praise that the 212 has gotten. In retrospect I should have picked up something a bit better but overall I'm happy.

name: ARCTIC Liquid Freezer III 360 56.3 CFM Liquid CPU Cooler

specs.CPU Socket:
AM4
AM5
LGA1700
LGA1851

comments: For cooling, I went with the Liquid Freezer III 360. This is my first AIO, and so far, I'm very pleased with it. I replaced the stock fans with three Arctic P12 MAX, which probably hasn't made any real difference. Maybe it's a little louder than stock; I don't know. I had heard that the mounting onto the mobo would be a little tricky, but I experienced no problems at all with the installation .
Keeps 7800X3D cool under load, good value

Bought for 90 USD from Amazon in January 2025. Planned on getting a Phantom Spirit 120 Evo, but reconsidered seeing various great reviews for this AIO for $40 more. Runs very quiet and is overkill for my current CPU (so I've been told), though still am considering an air cooler in the future.
Keeps temps right where they should be!
Keeps my CPU cool, but the mounting process is a bit unclear

Best value cooler for power hungry chips imo. No rgb, no ******** displays, just a beefy thick radiator. Keeps a 253 watt 14900k under 70°. The installation on Intel is a breeze, no extreme pressure or force required. The pump is somewhat noisy at 100% speed, but it is PWM controlled and can be slowed down significantly with a fan curve. Stock fans connection that goes through the tubes is weird as it only has 2 pins. I ended up wiring the fans myself with a proper 4 pin cable. VRM fan is comically small, but I guess it does... something. At least it is quiet even at full rpm.
Really effective, but its a big beefy cooler. Literally bigger than my GPU

Clearly very capable. I had a little trouble mounting the block onto the CPU mounts. I suspect the mounting brackets have a tiny bit of play when screwing in, so they weren't weren't exactly perfectly positioned on my first attempt. This stopped the block from screwing in. Would've liked more than 0.8g of MX-6, but this is adequate for at least a couple applications. Super pricing.
I checked compatibility with the motherboard before purchasing. Highly recommended to do so beforehand as the pump/waterblock can be impeded by high VRM and/or NVME SSD heatsinks.

The best AIO out there, while also one of the cheapest? Count me in. Keeps my overclocked + undervolted 9800X3D below 60c while gaming. Only drawback, but I won’t take off a start for that, is its mounting mechanism. Could be easier. My suggestion is, mount the 2x provided black metal rails ON THE PUMP first, and then try mounting all the thing on the motherboard, not the opposite way (which is what the manual says). If you go with what the manual says, the screws on the pump will NEVER reach the metal rails.
Good n' cheap.

comments: Cheap, silent, effective. Also looks nice.

Very good air cooler, especially when it comes to price-to-performance. Keeps my temps under 80c when using Cinebench @ 24c room temperature. This was also a safer option for me than getting an AIO and risking water leak.
Nice and quiet, I don’t think I can hear it up until about 50 percent fan speed which is barely ever. Seemed to be really good value too.

Easy to install, keeps my CPU cool under stress, and looks great in my case. What more could you ask for? I think it brings a tasteful level of RGB without going overboard. And for how cheap it is, it's a great value.
Its cheap, looks cool, lights up, and keeps my cpu plenty cool.

Got the RGB one because it was cheaper at the time. Replaced the middle fan with a P12 Max and at the side (over the RAM) only a slim one could fit without touching the cables that power the MOBO. Needed to dremmel the side bracket that holds the Noctua fan a little bit so the heatpipes didn't touch it, but it fits perfectly apart from that.

I chose this over ID Cooling's A620 Pro SE even though the PS120SE costs $5 more just because I did not like the build quality of the former unit.
AFAIK, Frost Spirit > Frost Commander > Phantom Spirit > Peerless Assassin. "SE" models have a small height difference (e.g. 154 mm vs 157 mm in heatsink specs for PS120SE vs PS120) but perform the same (fan specs/noise level/air flow et al.) and are cheaper. Just pick from any of the 4 models that fits in your budget and/or build aesthetic.
Refer:
What's the difference between all these Thermalright coolers?
It is a non-issue for me but I did notice that I had to put more pressure installing this cooler as compared to other CPU coolers I have installed in the past. Still, documenting here for posterity.
I had no issues with RAM clearance. Just check the dimensions of whatever RAM + CPU cooler combination you select. Thermalright's website might be lacking in design but they are very upfront about their product specs and do not hide anything from you.

I came across the cooler on my own as I knew I wanted a fan and not water cooled. After I did some research I found out that this is a really popular cooler. The price is amazing! Performance reviews showed that it was a really good cooler for half the price as its competitors. Easy to install. It does come with its own thermal paste but I used Arctic MX-6 paste instead. The size is a bit on the large end so I had to get low profile RAM stick for it to fit under the cooler's fan. Keeps my CPU temps very cool even under a load. I am now an advocate for the Thermalright brand.

This is one of highest value CPU coolers you can buy for $48CAD. It keeps my 7600x very cool~50°C under load and the fans are quiet. The only minor downside is the length of the ARGB cable. It is NOT long enough to run up and over the motherboard, behind and up from the bottom with a mATX motherboard. However, thanks to the coolers size, I could run it down the front of the motherboard and behind the graphics card without it being visible. Also, no matter what I do in the BIOS to the fan curves, it is impossible to make them stop spinning when idle. That might just be a skill issue though. This cooler fits in the NZXT H5 Flow 2023 with the front fan raised by ~5mm due to RAM clearance with a G Skill Trident RGB kit.
Great at cooling, but it takes up quite a bit of space. Regardless it's easy to set up and gets the job done!

name: ARCTIC Liquid Freezer III 360 A-RGB 48.82 CFM Liquid CPU Cooler

specs.CPU Socket:
AM4
AM5
LGA1700
LGA1851

comments: I picked this cooler for its reviews, and boy is it awesome. I have no experience with other AIOs, but this thing can handle my 14900KF under load, and still remain pretty quiet, atleast with headphones on. Easy installation, and it came with MX-6 and a contact frame which I didn't know, which is even more awesomer.

Quiet, cool, and great-looking. Very easy to connect with any RGB software. At idle, it keeps the Ryzen 7 9800X3D below 50°C, and you can’t even hear it. Even at full speed, it runs smoothly and provides strong cooling. It also comes with thermal paste.
Affordable liquid cooler with reasonable performance.

If I had to describe this cooler, I'd describe it the same way I would myself: quiet, cool, and surprisingly good-looking. The included fans are quiet, and the split cable for the fans, pump, and vrm fan makes setting separate curves easy as pie. I do wish it wasn't as massive, and that the daisy chaining for the fans was a little cleaner, but those are very minor complaints all things considered. Update: replaced the included fans with D30-120 Reverse blades as I'm moving it to a side intake instead of top exhaust.

In all honesty I expected CPU temps to be lower even performing a CPU torture test like Cinebench multi-threaded, but 80ºC with some 15ºC ambient temps is uncomfortable, to say the least, considering summers where I live can easily reach 40ºC. It's possible it's partially on me (I have a massive skill issue and I had to mount the cooler thrice), though. That aside, instalation was a lot easier than was foretold by reviewers and some friends with variants of this product.

Its a great AIO for the price. keeps my 7800X3D under 78C when gaming for long periods of time. Only reason i docked 1 star is when installing the cooler on the CPU... MAN its annoying. Make sure to not screw 1 side too much because it'll be a pain to screw the other side in.
Very easy to install and keep my 7800x3D below 50°C and come with thermal paste too.
Looks nice, keeps my PC cool, and runs quiet

Great AIO, mate told me to get this, easy install looks good just wish they included more thermal paste in the tube but overall great AIO people told me to go for an air cooler but i want to have very good temps in my build.
Looks great, but the CPU cooler is extremely hard to fit. Required multiple tries, and a lot of patience.

comments: My first air cooler. My experience with it was kinda nerve wracking, since the guy I bought it from didn't include the offset mounts, which I didn't realize until I put the thermal paste on. I had to wait 2 days while actively trying to keep my thermal paste from drying out. Other than that, I think it performs pretty well for an air cooler, being slightly worse than the 240 AIO that I had. It is a little louder than I expected, but it keeps my CPU cool.
It cooled my 5600x and now the same one is cooling my 9950x3d: I'm guessing there are now better options out there but I personally got my money's worth from this part.

Ever since i saw Matt lee's video on the Black H5 Flow, i KNEW i had to get my hands on this cooler. It has surpassed my cooling expectations by miles. Just make sure you have the AM5/LGA adapter for your build.

Good quality cooler thats very quiet. However it is older now and is beaten in performance by far cheaper thermalright air coolers. This has always been overpriced and not really good enough for i9s but it has its benefits.

The mounting brackets are pretty annoying to work with, but they function great and aren't easy to break so I got over it. This cooler isn't cheap, but I didn't want water cooling so I went with it. Cools my Ryzen 9 9900X great.

Keeps my i7 12700K very cold, on idle hovers around 48C, and under High graphic settings can go as high as 65C. The only complaint I have is how I wish Noctua would realize that the 2nd 140mm fan they provide will not fit nicely as it will be sitting over the RAM and would not be flush with the heat sinks. So in order to have it nice and flush on the front I put a 120mm Noctua Fan and change the brown silicon edges for white ones off of amazon.
Overall, a great wind cooler that still performs as good or even better than many water coolers out there for a great price.

For cooling, I went with the reliable Noctua NH-D15, expecting that its massive heatsink and two fans paired with a low-wattage CPU would result in very cool temperatures. The Noctua cooler just barely fits and clears the RAM. Under 100% load in AIDA64, the CPU's maximum temperature is 65°C, and the GPU's maximum temperature is 56°C.
Kept my Ryzen 9 5900X chilly even with overclocking. Been using it for a few years. Solid build quaility.
Classic 5 stars Noctua Cooler

Didn't want to deal with liquid cooling and this has worked perfectly so far for my Ryzen 9 7900X3D. CPU temp peaks around 58-60 playing games on max graphics, barely hits 70 when I'm intentionally stressing it. This won't fit many cases due to how bulky it is but was easy to fit inside the Hyte Y70.

comments: Very clean AIO and cools well, only problem is with NZXT Cam and me having to downgrade the application and turn off updates by force. Beware if you're buying NZXT right now as they are very slow with updating NZXT CAM.
It's very pretty! but pricey. I bought it for looks, but I am aware that it is overkill for my CPU.
NZXT CAM is a disaster after the last update and NZXT isn't giving a single ****.

I will say the parts feel a bit cheap and generic in quality but I haven't yet seen a better alternative in this price point for a white AIO. I countered this by swapping out the stock fans with some Lian Li 120mms, which also helps match the rest of the fans in my case. Was thinking of going with Lian Li's Galahad AIO but I heard a lot of horror stories about that one and decided to stick to NZXT. The NZXT cam app can be a little cumbersome at times but having Lain on the panel makes it worth every penny. You also have to make sure you plug it into the right fan slot on your motherboard or else the app will not detect your fan and it won't function at all.
On the flipside. is so much fun to mess around with and customize. Having a running GIF of Lain "guarding" my CPU has definitely given my build an aura. The cooler has also made my computer the quietest I've ever heard. Granted, I've only ever had gaming laptops, so my anecdote might not be worth much :P

The NZXT Elite 360 cooler comes with a pre-applied thermal paste, which I decided to use instead of cleaning it off and applying a new layer. So far, this decision hasn’t caused any issues, and the system operates efficiently.
it's insanely expensive but god it is So Gorgeous. (my temperatures are also always good) i'm just a girl 🎀 spending 250 bucks to have pretty GIFs in my PC is totally worth it!
It’s easy to install but why 4 stars ??? Bc it doesn’t even come with a darn am4 bracket, had to order one off eBay, the lcd screen has been great and temps are solid
pricey but is absolutely sexy and totally worth it, i love the convenience of the NZXT CAM software and how easy it is to use

Look it's expensive, but def worth if you are looking for pc looks. The screen looks fabulous and the nzxt app is very easy to use with control of the screen itself and the fans that are connected with it.
The screen looks really nice and is customizable, and temps are good.

name: ARCTIC Liquid Freezer III 240 56.3 CFM Liquid CPU Cooler

specs.CPU Socket:
AM4
AM5
LGA1700
LGA1851

comments: Cheap and good quality, i had no issue for installing it. Just follow the instruction and push the screw well. It keeps my CPU cold. It's very quiet. The radiator is thick so check the measurements of your RAM. No problem in the Corsair 4000D and the Gskillz.
Insane value for the price, matching or outperforming cooler that cost multiple times the cost of this.
pretty good

I'm using the fans that came with it.
Keeps 9800x3d reasonably cool under load. ~73c peak during CPU benchmarks while averaging 58c, ~43c idle (a little high idle probably because of external ambient temps and some case airflow constraints). Relatively easy to install, but I wish it came with a physical manual. I missed a step during installation because it wasn't listed in the online manual's "installation" section but in a separate "choose connector" section which was annoying because it meant removing it from the CPU mount after applying it to the CPU.
The radiator is quite thick so be sure to take that into account for your build.
Some people have complained about the screw length being too short for the CPU mount. I kinda get it, the screws are relatively short, but applying a little bit of pressure onto the mount made it a non-issue and they screwed into the threads properly.

Surprisingly good for a 240mm AIO. Never did I see my 9700x get above 70C and never do I see this 7950x3D get over 80C unless running a synthetic benchmark.
Great work Arctic!
I can't even see the fan spinning on the cpu, it's fantastic!
Thick radiator, strong pump, quiet fans, no RGB. Fantastic.

Based on my research and recommendations, this is the best cooler for an SFF build this year. I deducted one star because the stock fan on the radiator is a bit thick and touches the motherboard's wiring, preventing it from running properly. -- I ended up purchasing a fan grill instead of opting for a thinner fan like the Noctua. It's quiet and does a great job of controlling heat.

The lack of cables and ease of installation is a massive pro. It's whisper silent, with not a ton of weird pump noise that I seem to hear a lot in lianli and NZXT AIOs. Super quiet and for the price, punches well above its weight class.

I really thought I'd need a better cooler for my 9900X, but it turns out the Arctic Freezer III is built different. My 9900X idles at ~40C and never goes above 75C during load. According to reviewers this the best aio performance you can get on AM5.
The radiator is notably thicker (38mm compared to the standard 27mm), and the tubes are long and not very flexible. It may not fit in all cases so keep that in mind.

comments: Haven't done too much with this build, but so far from playing Monster Hunter Wilds, this cools the same for the 9700X as the Noctua NH-D15 Chromax does for the 7800X3D that's in my main build. In fairness, the 9700X is less power hungry than a 7800X3D. The Phantom Spirit may not look as impressive as a D15, but it's also ~1/4th the price. As long as the fans can last a few years without the bearings going out, it's a win. CPU Cooling solutions, along with PC Cases and monitors AND unlike GPUs, thankfully seem to be in a great spot so far in early 2025 with plenty decent and competitive options available.
Works great at cooling a 7800x3d. Fans sound good even when pushed to higher RPMs, making a deeper rumble than the higher pitched fans I'm used to.
Fantastic cooler probably more than a Core 15 13400F needed but bigger cooling=lower fans speed so im for it
Great CPU cooler. There really isn't much else to say. It performs well, it's easy to assemble and it's very quiet.

Remarkably performant for its price. However, while silent, the loudest frequencies still hit the ear hard. This is irrelevant since it's still quiet and performant, so I'm giving it the rating it deserves. Oh, and the free thermal paste is nice.

Cooling ability is great; CPU does not go over 75 degrees, even at continued 100% load. However, I could only fit one fan in the middle. The front of the cooler is partially blocked by the motherboard's USB3 header, and the back of the port is too small to accommodate a 120mm fan. In the end, I just mounted the 92mm fan that came included with my case as the "second" fan for the cooler. Still very good cooling performance.
Does what everybody said it would do. It keeps the CPU cool, and it's whisper quiet.
A third the price of the NH-D15, yet better performance in some scenarios. It just doesn't get better than that.
Really good performance for a very accessible price

Literally the best out there, aside from noctua. (Which costs four times as much) Cools my 3570k to 45c at 4.2ghz. In a good case, at 60 percent fans, i can get idle temps down to 22c. Absolutely silent at anything below 45 percent speed. It was pretty easy to install, and came with an entire tube of thermal paste, rather than having thermal paste applied to the bottom. Worth every penny.

comments: Installation was easy. NZXT has solved many previous headaches with this AIO, especially in the cabling department. Everything is routed through the radiator in one break-out cable, nothing is attached to the pump head, which is brilliant! The pump head is massive but I believe necessary to display all the metrics. CAM software has also come a long way from when I used it years ago. The big plus is that it doesn't tax system resources like it used to. The fans are also one assembly. No cables. No mess. Nice. The cooling performance is on par keeping my 9900X at agreeable temperatures under stress.
Easy to install, looks great but from some angles the screen looks weird but that might be my fault

Expensive cooler, has connection issues but it was because of the bad USB extender I had. Make sure you buy the NZXT Internal hub with this thing so it can be detected by the software. Looks amazing! Performs decently well but you can spend 75% less and have the same performance. Lets be real, the only thing that you want out of this CPU cooler is the screen and the looks. The software is really easy to use and can be used with all NZXT devices.
Very Beautiful AIO, with simple installation and cool centrepiece to any build
Beautiful LCD, great software, silent pump. Can’t go wrong.
It cools my CPU very well, the LCD screen is a nice touch.
Very aesthetically pleasing and I love the customisable LCD screen. A little pricey though..

A very good cooler, easy to install and didn't find any issues. All the connectors for the pump is easy to use and like how it uses SATA for power. Does use a USB port but this is standard. Performance of the pump and radiator are very good, and often find that I do not need to push the fans hard to reach optimal cooling. However, it is unfortunate it does not save your preferences for the screen configurations and colouring for the fans if NZXT CAM is turned off. I consider all of these software to be bloatware, and it's unfortunate I have to keep this running. But still a great AIO CPU cooler.
Super easy install. I love the screen, and the fans are super silent. Keeps my CPU nice and cool, even under load. The software could be better but still good.
Super easy to set up and NZXT CAM is easy to use

It was a well price AIO I knew i wanted one but I didn't want to spend hundreds on other AIOs I saw. Its doing its job just fine so no complaints on my end.
Great budget AIO, attractive ARGB and ran very cool & fairly quiet — the pump was a little audible at idle near startup but after a few seconds it ran smooth.

Works good for a budget AIO, i probably could of just gotten a air cooler but i wanted aesthetics. While installing it i had some difficulty mounting it to the mobo but that could just be a user error since i never built a computer before. Keeps the 7600x at 36c when idling
Very good temps with it but.. The installation was ridicules, the cables, the RGB, it was annoying but worth it in the end.

price to performance cant be beat. I can buy two of these for the price of others.

Only hard part was the wiring and cable management as the instructions don't really tell you what to do at all so had to reference some youtube videos.

comments: Overkill with current cpu, fantastic
Best Budget AIO
Thicc boi. Keeps my 9800x3d more than cool. Looks fantastic and has great value in performance and build quality.

Had it in a Be quiet 500dx case first, as front intake. Was a cramped fit but worked well. now in a Lian Li o11 evo rgb lamborghini edition, placed up top, it has room to breath. I am planning to maybe push pull mount it on the side eventually. But for now it's excellent for the price :)
Such an underated gem which holds my cpu cool
Silent and performant, with a light price.
According to multiple reviews, this is one of the best for the price ~$100. And so far the temp has been really good.
Best AIO especially for the price. Wish it came with more long screws so cases that already come with 3 front mounted intake fans can easily do push/pull on the front.

Pump is smooth and silent, one star off because they didn't make it easy to remove the cables meant to daisy chain the preinstalled fans, so I had to route them into the back of the case even though they're going unused. My 7700X idles at around 35-38C, but it hits that 83C mark when at 100% load. That could be number of user errors from bad fan curves to inadequate thermal paste application though, so it's not affecting my review, especially because for my use case my CPU only ever hits 100% load for short durations during shader precaching.

Best price/performance cpu cooler in the market, keeps a 9800X3D at 42 C while idle and around 50 C under load. The radiator is beefy at 38 mm while the fans are 25 mm so check the ram clearance and motherboard vrm heatsinks clearance.

Very good performance cooler, might be a bit expensive but the rgb is excellent

Looks awesome and seems to be keeping my CPU pretty cool, haven't got above 80 deg. C under heaviest load so far. The visual effects on the pump head are awesome and it comes with the three AF-120 RGB fans and an included fan/pump controller.

Ok for the price

I'm not sure about this cooler yet. For the price, absolutely a home-run. Install instructions are lacking at best. Let me explain:
I am questioning the AM5 mounting system for this cooler. The instructions say to install the water block bracket at an angle, line up the arrow on the block and the bracket and rotate clock-wise to secure it. Well, when I rotate the bracket, it doesn't lock in, rather it just sits in the block and will slide out and fall off the block very easily if you don't physically hold it on. This became an issue when it came time to install the block onto my CPU. As I stated already, it likes to rotate out and fall off since it won't lock in place. I was still able to install it, but I had to hold the bracket in place to prevent it from moving while I mounted the block to the CPU. Interestingly this cooler uses the factory mounting brackets that come on AMD motherboards, don't often see that, but it made installing the water block super easy minus the bracket issue.
So, since the bracket won't lock in properly, it makes the LED logo on the block look crooked, or un-level. This can't be the correct way to install the water block if you ask me. So far temps don't seem too bad, but I need to get a second monitor to check the real-time temps while I play a few games. So far it idles around 45-47C.
LEDs on the fans look good, fans are quiet enough. They're not Noctua or Be Quiet! fans, but they are certainly serviceable. The radiator came with one little bent fin on the top but it was hidden since its facing the top of my case so no real issue there. Tubing looks like, block looks like good quality. I would recommend getting a different thermal paste because the one provided seems very sketchy. It feels very thick and dry, not very spreadable. I might change the paste once I see my real time gaming temps.
Knocking off 1 star so far because of the bracket mounting issue. If I figure out a solution, I'll edit my review. Did anyone else with this cooler run into this problem, or am I an idiot for not doing something obvious to lock the bracket into place?

I wanted to replace the stock Wraith Stealth cooler because it was the source of most of the noise from my system. I would put my finger on the Wraith Stealth's fan to stop it and suddenly the system seemed near-silent. The Assassin King has a single fan and tower with five heat pipes, which seemed suitable for cooling my CPU--I don't overclock it. (I added this cooler before upgrading from a Ryzen 3600 to a Ryzen 5700X3D CPU, but I think it's able to cool the 5700X3D well enough.) A dual tower air cooler would cool more effectively, but my primary reason for adding this was to reduce noise and a dual tower air cooler would have two fans. The only thing that threw me off on this was the mounting on this GA II Trinity was different from previous models I had seen in youtube videos. I have no idea when Lian Li changed this but it must have been within the past few months. The model I got did not have the "clip" mounting brackets for AMD. I had to remove the top and bottom brackets from my MOBO, screw 4 long mounting pins into those holes in the MOBO, and then the mounting bracket that went onto the pump screwed onto the 4 long mounting pins. Corsair iCUE LINK TITAN 360 Review: Cooling Power With Style If you’re looking for a cooler that can keep up with your high-end gaming or streaming setup, the Corsair iCUE LINK TITAN 360 is here to blow you away. This thing packs a huge 360mm radiator, three beastly 120mm fans, and all the cool features you need to take your PC’s cooling to the next level—while looking awesome while doing it.
Seriously Powerful Cooling Let’s talk performance: the 360mm radiator means this cooler is built for heavy-duty cooling. Whether you’re pushing your CPU to the max with overclocking or gaming for hours, the three 120mm fans have got your back, keeping your rig cool and stable even under the most intense workloads.
Easy Control with iCUE One of the best things about this cooler is its iCUE integration. If you’re already familiar with Corsair’s iCUE software, you know it’s a game-changer. With iCUE, you can easily control fan speeds, RGB lighting, and even pump speeds all from your PC. Want to switch up the look of your system? Just use iCUE to play with the RGB effects—whether you want a chill vibe or a full-blown light show, it’s all at your fingertips.
Simple Installation Despite its massive 360mm radiator, the iCUE LINK TITAN 360 is actually pretty easy to install. Corsair’s tool-free mounting system makes it simple to get the cooler set up quickly, and the flexible tubing means you won’t be struggling to fit it into your case. Plus, the anti-vibration mounts keep everything nice and steady, making sure the cooler stays quiet.
Quiet But Mighty What’s impressive about this cooler is that, even though it’s packing some serious cooling power, it’s still super quiet. The fans run quietly when your system is chilling, but when you’re pushing your rig, they ramp up and keep the noise levels in check. It's like having all the performance without the noise.
Final Thoughts: A Killer Cooler With a Clean Look The Corsair iCUE LINK TITAN 360 is everything you need in a cooler: serious performance, easy control, and killer looks. If you’re building a high-performance rig and want something that can handle the heat while also looking awesome, this cooler is a no-brainer.

comments:
Very good cooler, knocked off a star because mounting on Intel LGA1700 and L1851 systems is rather tedious and not properly instructed. In fact, there's no instructions in the box at all and the instructions on their site and in their videos leaves out crucial details.
Nonetheless, it keeps my 12900K idling at ambient temperatures.

It does his job, keeps the Ryzen 7 9700X under 45 °C idle and never above 75 even when gaming.
Fixing the pump on the CPU was as painful as it gets!!
Update: just a note for who wants to use this AIO, it is quite thick, and since the pipe connectors are just a tiny bit (sub 1mm) larger than the radiator, if your case has exactly the 280mm of space for it, you might struggle to force it into position. I certainly had to apply some extra pressure to fit it in position in TheTower 200.

Really nice AIO for the money, I got this on sale as well. I chose the non RGB version for simplicity and better cable management. I am running it without the included VRM fan cap as it's in an SFF case and my motherboard already has a VRM fan. I like that they provide the option to control the pump and fans with a single cable or a split cable. Mounting it is pretty straightforward, to get the second screw into the CPU brackets you need to press quite hard but it's not too bad. I do wish the AIO tubes were able to rotate more at the CPU block so it would fit better in my use case. The pump is quiet enough for me and performs well even running at a constant 40%. I replaced the stock fans with some Noctua NF-A14s I had from my previous build. The included thermal paste has enough for 3-4 remounts which is nice. The screws that mount the rad to your case or bracket will poke into the rad fins and deform them, as long as you don't hit the water passages this seems fine
Considering that I had to remove one of the fans on the radiator to fit it in my system, and it still keeps CPU temps good, I have to commend this AIO's capability.

I have yet to see a comfortable mounting process for any cooler.
Aside from that, this essentially does everything I could ask for. Can be decently silent and cools my 7950X3D just fine.

Not a lot of bells and whistles - the radiator is very thick and the fan is simple. Which, doesn't feel like a super high quality piece but at the same time, keeping these things simple makes them more robust. So far it's doing a great job cooling.

Honestly, the new budget GOAT for AIOs. Stupid quiet for how much cooling you get, and was a breeze to install on Intel. Not seeing anything higher than 80C, even on CPU intensive games like BG3. I love the look of the block, and the no RGB is a plus for me.
Got it on sale during the Arctic Bday sale, but I'd probably buy it again for updating another build.

comments: AIO: Amazing aio, keeps the cpu running nice and cool even under load. The LCD screen is amazing and I would recommend it if trying to save some money if you are not going for the elite version. It runs super quiet and it is a very high quality aio. Only difference compared to the elite is the screen but if that doesnt bother you, go for this one, it will do the job very well.

So far I've run it for a month or so on my Ryzen 9 1900X3D and have had 0 issues with cooling. Peak temps I've seen it reach are 72 C and that's under extreme load with reletively high ambiant temps. I usually idle somewhere in the 43-48 C range. The front display is really nice as I can display my temps on that and the CAM software has a super cool mini mode that I keep open on my 3rd screen so I can always see the system info.
My cpu hasn’t overheated yet

Installing any asetek AIO is always a little sketchy, but otherwise as a cooler this is excellent. Included fans are fair, and pump remains inaudible at lower speeds. The screen has fairly limited functionality, and CAM considers average core temp CPU temp, which is misleading and not very useful. The major downside is having to use CAM, horrible piece of software lacking basic functionality. Also fairly expensive for a basic 360 AIO.

My NZXT Kraken 360: Ice-cold temps and sweet, sweet RGB! This AIO has my CPU chillin' like a penguin on vacation. Fans are whisper-quiet, and NZXT CAM makes tweaking colors and speeds a breeze. If you want a cooler that's both frosty AND flashy, look no further!

A simple and quiet RGB AIO cooler, it's easily able to cool down my CPU with anything that comes at it. With the software that support the cooler, NZXT CAM, you're able to customize the RGB lighting, fan speed, and see the temp of components with its monitoring system. Installing it was a breeze with its easy to follow instructions manual. If you're looking for a visual appealing but also significantly cooling AIO without breaking the bank to much, I would highly recommend this as a option.
Looks amazing, NXZT Cam software easy to navigate, keeps CPU cool, no complaints.

Otherwise quite happy with the cooler. Keeps my 5600X at 66C, even in Linpack Xtreme.
Overkill for my processor (12400f) but nonetheless is very silent and good looking. Worked perfect out of the box, and the instructions were perfectly clear during installation.

A clean air cooler capable of handling high-end CPUs. When I attempted to install it in another build, I encountered an issue where every time I managed to screw one side onto its base, the other side immediately lifted up. I returned it and was informed that the cooler has a spring-loaded mechanism. So, I decided to give it another try in this build. It turned out to be easier than I had anticipated; it simply requires a bit of pressure after screwing in the first screw.
I would have deducted 1 star because of the uncomfortable installation; however, upon realizing that this cooler effectively cooled the CPU, maintaining a maximum temperature of 70 degrees (no overclocking), I decided not to deduct any stars. This cooler rivals the Noctua NH-D15.

comments: Looks stunning, it's completely silent on idle and very quiet on load. This is a PC component I will use for all my future builds until I die. Best PC purchase I've ever made.

It can be a bit loud when the fans are going at full speed, for the CPU in the build I would recommend adjusting the fan curve as the CPU never gets too warm. I don't know if it is because of the thermal paste, the cooler or both but the results are good and most of the time I have a silent computer.
Runs quiet compared to the other fans in the case and keeps the cpu cool during gaming.

Hugemongous cooler of insane sizeability. It barely fits the S340, but does so with enough millimeters for me to add a little custom faceplate to hide the heatsink pipes and show off the lovely metal Noctua decal. The sleek Chromax design is gorgeous and highly effective. If you need less hugeness, the NH-U9S is also fantastic. You may need to look for lower-profile RAM modules depending on your motherboard's layout.

Overpriced for what it is but I couldn't bring myself to dock a star. Silent even under the heaviest loads i use it at, keeps the CPU nice and cool, and comes with classic Noctua reliability, compatibility, and customer service. Also, i got mine for like $130 (the current display price is from MemoryC which is like $100 more expensive)
Super quiet even when running at 100% percent, which I love.

I'll say for my use case, this works great. Anything heavier and you'll need a big AIO to keep up with this chip. Noctua's guidance on this on their website is misleading, which is why I'm taking off a star. It's whisper quiet, though, and was a tactile pleasure to work with getting it installed. No clearance issues whatsoever.

I fully intend to stay air cooled for the foreseeable future so I didn’t want to cheap out. Noise was a priority here so I spent a little extra for the best. The d15 was another option but seeing as the u12a performs very closely with less of a footprint I opted for the smaller option. I had intention to vertically mount my gpu and I wanted as much space as possible. It performs amazing and stays quiet. I never need to run the fans above 50%. They normally hover between 10%-30%. Practically silent. Also I went chromax black because: what would Batman do. 10/10

Running great so far, haven’t optimized fan profiles but was idle with my 7800X3D at 29 C. Was gaming into the high 50s touched lows 60s for a bit but didn’t have air condition on in house. Cracked open the door into the storage closet and temps dropped back down into 50s again playing Baulder’s Gate 3 and Doom all ultra maxed out 1440p. I will have to optimize the fan profiles for the cpu fans and rest of case. But looks amazing so far. I am just wondering if it will match or beat my old Thermaltake Frio OCK I had. That thing would keep my 4960X at a gaming temp of mid 40s. I could idle at 23C. Will need to turn on air condition in house as it wasn’t on either. Just was ambient temp.
I will post updates and bench’s once I get everything optimized in the coming weeks. Also, no tweaks or undercooking done to 7800X3D yet. Have to get baselines first then go from there. Beautiful look with other black Noctua case fans, really slick and very impressive.
Update: I have had short 5 second or so spikes in into the high low 70s, however this was a result of me having all the doors closed in an enclose room. When I have both doors open both 7800x3d and the 7900 xt stay in the mid 60s. Most games gaming in 1440 p stay in the 60-65 degree Celsius range. When I download games from steam the cpu will spike to 70C under load downloading games blazing fast. I still have games with central ac on. So I will likely post an update during dog days of summer. As soon as the game exits temps come down immediately back to idle temps.

Amazing cooler, which is to be expected from Noctua. Practically silent at idle and during gaming. Probably a bit overkill for my CPU, but its great to have that thermal headroom. The included NF-A12x25 perform flawlessly and are the quietest fans I've ever used.

comments: Super cute, I love the look, extremely silent! The initial one I purchased from Newegg had a slight noise to it. Sounded like there was a rock stuck in the pump. I went to BestBuy, talked to GeekSquad and they advised it wasn't supposed to sound like that, and that it was defective, so I returned it back to Newegg and purchased the same model in store. Newegg refunded without a problem, and the new one sounds as intended, quiet! Upon researching the noise, others were saying to shake it or turn it upside down because of bubbles, and that is not the case. Just submit a warranty claim as the issue is the reason of being defective. Overall, the screen is beautiful and has a rich feel to it. The RBG version of this cooler, the fans looked and felt extremely cheap. This is the better version and is worth the price!

Always been a fan of NZXT products. When I saw there was a newer version of the Kraken, I knew it wouldn't disappoint. The screen looks amazing, the noise is minimal, and my 9800X3D is happy.

The Kraken Elite 360mm AIO has been an excellent cooler for my Ryzen 9 9950X3D, keeping temps low even under heavy loads. Installation was straightforward, and the adjustable pump orientation made it easy to fit into my build. The IPS LCD screen is a nice touch, allowing for custom displays and real-time system monitoring.
Cooling performance is top-notch, with the static pressure fans providing great airflow while staying quiet. The CAM software integration makes it easy to adjust fan curves and monitor temps. Overall, it’s a reliable and stylish AIO that performs as great as it looks.

Price might drive you away but this cpu cooler has managed to be my favorite part out of all the others despite the fact that it wasn't my initial choice for cpu cooling. I went with this instead of the iCUE H150i ELITE LCD but could have probably went with the non elite or older elite version. Display is awesome, fans are clean, sleek and having no RGB makes it look nicer imo. The NZXT CAM software is really nice and the customization and tweaking options are diverse. Install was fairly easy too with all the required cables being nicely sleeved.

This Kraken Elite 360 has done a great job so far of keeping my i7-14700k cool. Idle temp is around 30-32 C, and under load it usually stays around 65 C or lower. The configurable circular screen is great. Two complaints though: the LED ring is not diffused very well, making individual LEDs visible; also, the sleeves on the tubes are not very smooth and get crimped easily.
Good performance with fans at lower rpm. However the data cable moved to rad outlet is not fully sheathed, which takes away from the otherwise clean look.

Beauty of an AIO. Works great cooling a 9800x3d. Pumps relatively quiet. I LIED. The pump failed on me, started making a grinding noise. The noise only seems to disappear when at 100%... only good thing left is the display 😔

Pros:
38mm thick radiator provides more cooling then standard thickness radiators
VRM fan is actually effective
The leaf spring on the pump provides nice pressure on the CPU
Comes with a contact frame for Intel Chips
Comes with offset bracket mount for AM5 chips
The tubes are nice and long, allowing this to be mounted to the top or side of a case
Cons:
The pump can be a pain to get mounted into the AM5 offset bracket mount due to the leaf spring
On the underside of the brackets for AM5 chips are tiny paper thin nuts stamped/formed into the metal of the bracket. If you tighten down the pump to much or to hard it will break those nuts and allow them to spin freely, making it impossible to get the pump off without undoing the entire bracket system. (I had to buy another one of these because of that issue)
Minor Grievances:
The pump and hoses coming from it may have clearance issues with certain motherboards (Ex. ASUS X870E HERO and it's top most M.2 Heatsink)
The cables for the fans and the RGB run up one of the hoses and connect to the included RGB fans. If you are using different fans these cables may be redundant and are very hard to hide.
The tubes used are hard and don't like to bend a lot
The included cables for the RGB on the VRM header and to power the pump and fans are long making cable management a bit difficult
Final Thoughts:
I would recommend this to anyone who wants a 420mm AIO liquid cooler for their system. Arctic makes some very nice liquid coolers with excellent cooling to price performance. The leaf spring design for the Liquid Freezer III series is nice but also a pain, especially if you are on an AM5 chip. The inclusion of a contact frame for Intel chips is a nice touch from Arctic. The offset brackets for AM5 chips could use a revision. As mentioned above, there are tiny paper thin nuts on the underside of the bracket where the pump screws into. If you screw down the pump to tight or to hard (which is easy to do because of the leaf spring used), those tiny nuts will break and spin freely. Which makes it impossible to get the pump off and you will have to undo the entire bracket system to get the pump off. I had this happen to the first one I bought and I had to buy a new one.
Great cooler, working well so far.

Does not handle quick cpu temp fluctuations from sudden loads very well, will jump from 40c to low 50c quickly. But under extended heavy loads it has never allowed the 7600X3D to get over 77c. The removable pump fan is an awesome feature for easy of installation and a fun party trick to just rip a part out of your machine. RGB works and looks good, fans work great and are relatively quiet.
4 stars because this thing is a bear and a half to mount properly while solo. The screws on the mounting hardware are a pain to get started, you need enough force to bend the spring steel tension plate to get the screws started, but not so much that you cause thermal paste to thin out on the cpu... A different mount solution or an installation aid would be much appreciated in future releases.

Massive cooler - one of the best performance to price cooler. Has RGB on the cooler mount. Has integrated VRM cooling fan. Multiple cable options available for individual fan/radiator pump control. Delivers amazing cooling performance within reasonable noise limits. Its a steal under 100 quid.

I've used Arctic Liquid Freezer AIOs in a few builds. Generally they are one of the best, if not the best performing AIOs on the market with the others being Lian Li GA II Trinity and EKWB EK-Nucleus. Unfortunately EK seems to be on the economic ropes right now and may not survive. Some YouTube tech channels have cut ties with them due to their business practices. Lian Li has always been good, their RMA and customer support has been great, although I have had two of their AIOs fail on me. So, that leaves Arctic as the most, at this point, reliable. This model is an improved model for them. I think it is a better aesthetic design and easy to install. It's also inexpensive relative to other AIOs.
For me, also, they are one of the few companies offering a 420mm radiator. So, that was really the deciding factor.
Quiet as hell and keeps my cpu extremely cool.

Runs quietly and excellently. The engineering design is clearly top-grade. The mounting bracket is a little unusual but not difficult at all to setup, even for a first time pc builder. It comes with all the tools you need, including a long screwdriver. A little big in the case.
Wow. Wow. Wow. Beautiful and cools like a dream. There's a reason why its the direct competition to AIOs and Noctua, nice and silent too
Does a great job at cooling CPU's, looks good, and is very easy to install.

Big, beefy, and quite the thermal exhausting beast, especially for how quiet it runs. Mine arrived with some lightly bent fins and what looked like surface wear on the leading edges where the fan and clips had vibrated and shifted against the surface. Very tight memory clearance, stick to memory that has no extra frills and just a low profile heat spreader.

It's still a great cooler all in all, but just barely handles modern high-end Intel CPUs. It was pretty good for my 12600K and I hoped to be able to keep it for the 13700K upgrade, but it struggled a little. It was fine on most gaming scenarios but let the 13700K throttle on intensive CPU loads.
I don't think it's a great option for modern builds anymore. Unless you can find it really cheap, there are other options with comparable performance for much better prices (aka Thermal Right's Peerless Assassin).
If you still want to go high-end, I'd recommend stepping up to Arctic's Liquid Freezer III 360 AIO, which will give you the best thermal performance in the market as of Apr/2024 for not too much more money.

I read so many reviews saying this cooler is hell to setup, but I must say it was pretty easy, and I love that it came with a magnet-tip screw-driver. It tames my CPU pretty well, max 90 degrees Celsius so far that I've seen under heavy gaming load, it's also pretty quiet.
Overkill for my i5 13600k but that just means my CPU will last forever. Keeps temps down while being super quiet. be quite's fans are a marvel of engineering.
Does the job well even on a 7950X3D despite being an air cooler, but I'm not planning on OC'ing. Mounting/installation was simple, no idea why so many people hate on this cooler for that reason.

comments:
Price was a little high, the 4 double sided screws can be a little tricky, it provides exceptional performances, runs quiet, AIO and RGB look amazing.
The Kraken elite was a good pick for the CPU that I bought. It was a little pricey compared to most other cpu coolers, but I couldn't get my hands on the Arctic II unfortunately, so I settled for good performance for a hefty price. First off, it looks great, it doesn't run super loud, and when I need it to kick on and cool off my Ryzen 9 7950x when it reaches those high temps, it does so. The cable management for it was pretty easy, at least with this version, there's not so many cables that are kind of in the way, it looks very neat and the whole thing was easy to put together with the single case fan. There was a 3 prong cable that came off of the CPU cooler that I didn't end up hooking into anything, and it still runs fine.
It had an Intel and AMD version for the AIO to connect to your motherboard. It came already installed with the Intel bracket, I had to switch it out for the AMD bracket and make sure to be careful not to bump into the Pre-applied thermal paste. It's nice that they include both versions and they are very easy to switch out. I will say 4 screws are double sided for connecting to the motherboard and at first glance they have the same thread but they do not, make sure you install it correctly. The pre-applied thermal paste on the bottom of the AIO was also super nice, you just have to be careful not to bump into it at all when you set it down in your CPU and let it go. And the AIO itself is beautiful, the customization is awesome, people give NZXT a real hard time with their software but I think if you understand computer software, it's not that hard.
A little pricey but went with NZXT on a lot of the computer components so felt necessary to get the Kraken Elite. Worth the price though this cooler is beautiful and powerful.

Pros: Big and beautiful display with a lot of customization options. The cordless design on the pump looks very clean. The Kraken Elite V2 also has great performance keeping my 13900K ~8c cooler than my previous Corsair H150i Elite AIO under stress testing.
Cons: The pump has a rattle/grinding sound when set to less than 40% speed (~1900rpm or less). I never have my pump set that low so it's not much of an issue, but I have read it's pretty common, so something to keep in mind.
The 2.7 inch LCD screen is awesome with gif feature. It has some coil whine under load, but acceptable.
